snippet: The generals’ willingness to submit to civilian authority will determine whether last year’s uprising lives up to its billing as a democratic revolution or amounts instead to a coup.
abstract: Egypt's ruling generals' willingness to submit to civilian authority will determine whether last year's uprising lives up to its billing as a democratic revolution or amounts instead to a coup; it is among the most consequential questions for the country's allies, like the United States and Israel, and for the next Egyptian president. Photo (M)

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK; Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: CAIRO -- Two weeks before Egypt's presidential election begins, the leading candidates are adopting a deferential tone toward the current military rulers even as the generals make clear that they expect to maintain much of their autonomy and influence after their pledged handover of power. Fifteen months after the generals seized power at the ouster of Hosni Mubarak, how much they now submit for the first time to civilian authority will determine whether last year's uprising lives up to its billing as a democratic revolution or amounts instead to a coup. It is among the most consequential questions for Egypt's allies, like the United States and Israel, and for the next Egyptian president.

headline.main: Candidates In Egypt Work To Mollify The Military
